instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20V, 0 Amps - waste of time?
threads.message:
PPBUS is 8.6V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> 3.26V
battery LED is on

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>P5VS4_PHASE</SIGNAL> are all constantly jumping around, cant get a proper measurement but they're certainly not ok.

CPUvcore is at 0V and not cycling.

Should I pack this thing back up or is there anything to check out?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20V, 0 Amps - waste of time?
threads.message:
I would not recommend to waste time on it.
If you solve a power problem, it can come back for CPU issue.
The client will claim for warranty, even you didn't even touch CPU area...

If you have time to spend, check for short on all secondary voltages; big coils and pages 50/51.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20V, 0 Amps - waste of time?
threads.message: No time to spend, or desire to deal with warranty when the CPU dies. Thanks for the advice, this is a no-fix.
